titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Philip Barry Papers
titlestmt.author: by Will Baker

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 05:34

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Philip Barry Papers document Barry's development and career as a playwright, from his earliest production at Yale in 1919 to his final work in 1949. The Papers are composed chiefly of Barry's notes, sketches, and drafts of his plays, materials relating to the production and publication of his plays, and correspondence with friends, family, fans, and colleagues in the worlds of theater and literature. Additional materials are also present, including scripts of plays by other authors, college and workshop notes, press clippings, and pamphlets and photographs relating to professional and social organizations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Acquired from Ellen Barry, 1940-1961 and from unidentified sources.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Philip Barry Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Philip Barry Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection includes materials previously identified by the following call number: Za Barry.
This finding aid was produced from a previously existing card set in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are available on microfilm. Consult Access Services for further information.

bioghist.head: Philip Barry (1896-1949)
bioghist.p: Philip Jerome Quinn Barry (1896-1949) was a 20th-century American playwright most widely known for comedies he authored during the 1920s and 1930s, including Paris Bound (1927), Holiday (1928), and The Philadelphia Story (1939). Born in Rochester, New York, Barry was the third and youngest son of a successful Irish immigrant father and an Irish-American mother from Philadelphia. After graduating from Yale in 1919, Barry attended George Pierce Baker's legendary 47 Workshop at Harvard, where he won the prestigious Richard Herndon Prize in 1922 for The Jilts . Subsequently produced by Herndon on Broadway as You and I , this script was the first of several composed before1930 that would establish Barry's reputation for high comedy and repartee. Together with the comedies of manners for which he was most popularly received, Barry authored a number of serious dramas tending toward religious and existential themes, including Tomorrow and Tomorrow (1931) and the more experimental Hotel Universe (1930) and Here Come the Clowns (1938). Barry's career as a playwright peaked in 1939 with the production of The Philadelphia Story , starring Katharine Hepburn, which was adapted to the screen the following year in a film featuring Hepburn, James Stewart, and Cary Grant.

Barry married Ellen Semple (1898-1995) in 1922. The two divided their time primarily between their homes in Manhattan and Mount Kisco, New York. They were the parents of two sons, Philip Semple Barry and Jonathan Peter Barry, and a daughter who died in infancy in 1933. Philip Barry died of a heart attack in 1949 at the age of 53.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Philip Barry Papers document Barry's development and career as a playwright, from his earliest production at Yale in 1919 to his final work in 1949. The Papers are composed chiefly of Barry's notes, sketches, and drafts of his plays, materials relating to production and publication, and correspondence with friends, family, fans, and colleagues in the worlds of theater and literature. Additional materials are also present, including scripts of plays by other authors, college and workshop notes, press clippings, and pamphlets and photographs relating to professional and social organizations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: I. Writings, 1918 - circa 1949. II. Subject Files, 1921-1949. III. Correspondence, 1921-1949. IV. Other Papers, 1917-1950. V. Plays by Others, 1933-1941.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title. Within titles, files are arranged in roughly chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains versions of works by Philip Barry in various stages of completion, including thirty plays, two screenplays, one opera libretto, one novel, and one short story. The material includes notes and sketches (holograph, typescript, and carbon, some corrected), final scripts (carbon), and proofs (some corrected) of these writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains files relating to the production and publication of Barry's plays and other writings. Materials include contracts, box office and royalty statements, budgets, bills, receipts, theater ephemera, and correspondence relating to specific works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Incoming correspondence is arranged alphabetically. Outgoing correspondence and telegrams to and from Barry are grouped separately at the end of the series, each arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of personal and business correspondence to and from Philip Barry in the form of holograph and typescript letters (mostly signed), telegrams, and holograph drafts of telegrams. The correspondence relates chiefly to the writing, publication, and productions of Barry's plays. Much of this content is from writers, actors, publishers, and producers sending notes of encouragement and congratulations to Barry, and it extends to letters of appreciation from audiences, discussions of published reviews, and requests for work. Most of the remaining correspondence is of a more personal nature, primarily from Barry's immediate family members and close friends.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of professional and personal papers existing in a variety of formats. The professional papers include statements and agreements with theaters and professional asssociations, legal literature pertaining to the taxation of authors' income, and notes, drafts, and clippings relating to Barry's plays. Personal papers include college class notes in notebooks and index cards, family correspondence, pamphlets, photographs, deposited checks, and other related material.

did.unittitle: Agreement draft, Authors' Corporation, Play Producing Department
Bills, price lists, and other papers relating chiefly to personal purchases
Membership dues statement, Authors League of America
Academic records and other school-related papers, Philip Barry Jr. and Jonathan Barry
Letters to and drawings by Marian White
Correspondence and other papers relating mostly to employment at the U.S. Embassy in London
Correspondence and other papers relating to plays by Barry
Ephemera and photographs relating to social organizations in the arts
Notebook inscribed with notes and ideas
Correspondence relating to plays by Barry
Legal papers relating to taxation of authors (Goldsmith Case)
L'Empereur de Chine (2 editions), Fernand Lger
Index cards inscribed with notes relating to playwriting
Notebooks and loose leaves inscribed with notes and ideas
Loose manuscript and typescript leaves of various scripts
Blank folio scrapbook, titled in gilt on the cover, "P. B. Without Love "

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of a collection of nine carbon scripts of plays by authors other than Philip Barry.

Garrett, Oliver H. P., and Fritz Lang. Hell Afloat
